prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: One of the most common methods used by employers to protect their confidential information is the restrictive covenant. Such covenants can take various forms and generally seek to restrain an employee's post-employment activities within a specified geographical area for a certain period of time.[1] This section will consider restrictive covenants, particularly in relation to the use of confidential information.[2]

The courts have specifically acknowledged the wisdom of restrictive covenants in appropriate circumstances. In the well-known English case of Printers & Finishers Ltd. v. Holloway,[3] the court stated:

If [an employer] is right in thinking that there are features in the [employer's] process which can fairly be regarded as trade secrets and which their employees will inevitably carry away with them in their heads, then the proper way for the plaintiffs to protect themselves would be by exacting covenants from their employees restricting their field of activity after they have left their employment, not by asking the court to extend the general equitable doctrine to prevent breaking confidence beyond all reasonable bounds.

While confidential information can be protected in its own right, through a restrictive covenant, an employer may be able to achieve wider protection than would otherwise be available. While it is generally not possible to restrain an employee from using his or her personal skills,[4] it is often difficult to distinguish such skills from legitimate business information worthy of protection. In many cases, a restrictive covenant will ensure that the court draws the line at a point that protects the employer's information. However, even if a restrictive covenant is clear and unambiguous, it must not be an overly broad restriction on the former employee's activities.[5]

As has been seen previously, the existing case law has helped to create uncertainty over many aspects of the employment relationship, particularly the post-employment duties of employees in relation to customer information. As a result, many employers have sought to protect their interests in information and customers by way of restrictive covenants.

The non-competition clause in Husky Injection Molding Systems Ltd. v. Schad[6] prevented Schad until September 22, 2010 from carrying on, being concerned with or interested in any undertaking which in whole or in part was substantially competitive with the business carried on by Husky within the respective territories in which such business were then carried on. Covenants in restraint of trade are to be strictly construed. The business that Schad was not to substantially compete against was defined as “the business of the designing, manufacturing and sale of injection molding equipment and systems for the plastics industry and the providing of related services thereto”. At no time before the expiry of the non-competition clause did Athena sell any injection molding machines or related services. Athena could have designed or manufactured its A150 machine during the time of the covenant not to compete and would not have been acting contrary to the covenant so long as it was not selling machines during the term of the covenant. The trial judge did not accept the argument that merely designing and developing machines, or even owning shares in Athena, was a breach of the covenant not to substantially compete with Husky.[7]

In some circumstances, restrictive covenants may apply to independent contractors. In Community Credit Union Ltd. v. Ast,[8] the Alberta Court of Queen's Bench held that although Ast was an independent contractor and not an employee, the nature of his employment justified a covenant prohibiting soliciation of customers and the establishment of his own business that would be likely to appropriate the employer's trade connection with its customers.

The common law traditionally treated all contracts restraining employees as contracts of imperfect obligation and as being void as against public policy. For example, in Triplex Safety Glass Co. v. Scorah,[9] the court concluded as follows:

… no employer is entitled to prevent his employee from making use, in the service of any persons or on his own account, of any experience or skill which the employee has gained during his term of service with the employer … any contract which attempts to prevent him making use of such skill or knowledge is not enforceable.

This general rule has been relaxed as the courts have recognized that, in some circumstances, allowing an individual to contract in restraint of freedom furthers the employee's interests and the interests of the general public. The leading case in this area of the law, Nordenfelt v. Maxim Nordenfelt Guns and Ammunition Co.,[10] established the foundational principles which must be addressed:

The public have an interest in every person's carrying on his trade freely: so has the individual … But there are exceptions: restraints of trade and interference with individual liberty of action may be justified by the special circumstances of a particular case. It is a sufficient justification, and indeed it is the only justification, if the restriction is reasonable—reasonable, that is, in reference to the interests of the parties concerned and reasonable in reference to the interests of the public, so framed and so guarded as to afford adequate protection to the party in whose favour it is imposed, while at the same time it is in no way injurious to the public.

Whether a particular covenant is enforceable will depend upon the facts of the individual case. In Yellowhead Petroleum Products Ltd. v. United Farmers of Alberta Co-Operative Ltd.,[11] the court confirmed that:

… whether a particular covenant is reasonable in any particular case is largely fact-driven. While previous decisions can provide guidance, they rarely telegraph the result in other cases. In J.G. Collins Insurance Agencies at p. 924 Dickson J. stated:

It is important I think, to resist the inclination to lift a restrictive covenant out of an employment agreement and examine it in a disembodied manner, as if it were some strange scientific specimen under microscopic scrutiny. The validity, or otherwise, of a restrictive covenant can be determined only upon an overall assessment of the clause, the agreement within which it is found and all of the surrounding circumstances.
A covenant in an employment contract will be subjected to greater scrutiny than one which is part of the consideration for sale of a business.[12]
In general, the courts will be wary of restrictive covenants, and this is particularly so where it appears that the employee had little choice but to acquiesce to the covenant.
